{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3570736,"name":"","username":"ZWORX52","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/z/f1d935/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-28T00:49:08.883Z","cooked":"

Hello,

I am a student programmer for FRC team 5735, trying to get computer vision working for our robot. After much deliberation, we decided that our goal this season would be to get reef alignment with pose estimation and a triple PID for X translation, Y translation, and rotation. I’d previously tried two different approaches. One considered a line that went through the branch the driver was trying to align to and was perpendicular to the reef side and using a PID to drive to that – essentially handling the left-right (when facing the side of the reef the robot is aligning to) and rotational alignment processes. The other was using PathPlanner’s OTF (on-the-fly) pathfinding algorithms, but they were overcomplicated and not precise enough (the path-to-point command provided by PPLib explicitly states it’s imprecise, and the “pathfind to, then follow a short path” alternative that was recommended (in the docs, see ‘pathfinding’ on pathplanner.dev) was both more complicated and made unnecessary movements that induced fear of odometry drift), so we scrapped all of that and moved back to a simple three-PID system.

We’re using CTRE’s swerve drive library (with generated code using Phoenix Tuner X) to control our swerve drive as we have the necessary hardware. It’s too late in the season to switch to another option (most likely), but that looks likely to be an off-season project. That library manages a pose estimator (meaning it handles the update() function with the odomotry). I’ve been feeding it data from our Limelight 3G whenever it’s available according to the LimelightHelpers library (using getBotPoseEstimate_wpiBlue_MegaTag2 as described in Limelight’s docs (AprilTag pipelines → Robot Localization with MegaTag2 → Using WPILib’s Pose Estimator), but replacing m_poseEstimator in the code with our drivetrain instance, as it exposes both addVisionMeasurement and setVisionMeasurementStdDevs). We’ve made a few modifications but the main idea is still there; you can see the exact code here (function updateVisionMeasurement); it’s being actively revised. The estimated pose is retrieved throughout the codebase with this function (which I wrote) which seems to be correct (there’s not much documentation here).

I should mention that we’re also using pose estimation during the auto phase, so getting it to work well with Limelight input during tele-op would also benefit our autos drastically.

With the current code, the issue we’re noticing is that the pose estimator does not seem to incorporate vision measurements. Earlier in the season, with similar code but using the 2024 update of the CTRE library, it was clearly visible on a driver dashboard that the pose estimator was incorporating vision measurements: we’d drive the drivetrain around and the odometry would approximate the position, but the odometry isn’t perfect. Its drift would be corrected by a MegaTag2 estimate when an AprilTag became visible. Since then, it seems as if the pose estimator is ignoring vision measurements – when running an auto or spinning in place, there is no ‘jump’ in the pose estimator’s reported position that you’d expect (graphing the X/rotational components of the NT path SmartDashboard/Field/Robot). Instead, the behavior we see is consistent with the pose estimator running off of just odometry.

I’ve tried setting the standard deviations to only ever be 0.7 as described in the Limelight documentation and tried setting them to be even lower values, but I don’t know what the CTRE library uses internally as it’s proprietary and native. I’ve also tried using the standard deviations from the Limelight itself. No effect.

Making our own pose estimator instead of the CTRE-managed one doesn’t seem to be an easy option, because of the native nature of the library. The raw odometry measurements aren’t very easy to access, I don’t think, but more importantly I don’t think that should be the solution. I’d like to leave that as a last resort.

I tried occasionally resetting the pose estimator with a MT1 or MT2 reading, for example just before running the PIDs, but that both never quite got the desired results (the still-existent drift would render it unreliable at best; this game is quite precise) while also running contrary to how pose estimators are supposed to work. Additionally, MT1 has the drawback that it’s sometimes very wrong with no warning, and if my gyro (a Pigeon 2.0) drifts, MT2 is worse than useless, so this approach would only have ever worked 80% of the time, with a not-rare-enough chance of Very Bad results.

Sorry that you have to find the docs yourself; there’s a limit of two links in a post for new users.

Happy to help people trying to help me.

Make sure you have this code at the end of your CommandSwerveDrivetrain to convert your vision timestamps to the documented time base; it was added to the generated project in a post-kickoff release.

As you can see in the first link, the timestamps come straight from LimelightHelpers, which I trust does this correction for me.
But if this were the case, it would never have worked; as I wrote in paragraph 4 it used to work. I was also using LimelightHelpers to fetch the timestamps with that code.
Thanks for the suggestion either way; I’ll try it out!

Limelight and PhotonVision both report an FPGA timestamp, which is the default time base of the WPILib pose estimator and what we used last year. However, as is mentioned in our addVisionMeasurement documentation, we now use the time base of our Utils.getCurrentTimeSeconds() (i.e. the time base of CAN frames), which is NOT the same as FPGA time. As a result, you need to convert FPGA time to our time base using the linked code.

bhall-ctre:

we now use the time base

This mistake seems to come up a ton. What’s the reason for the change and do you think there’s a way to help future folks out?

I wonder, if it’s not already done, if it’s possible to include these two overrides in the Phoenix X-generated project. That would at least help.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-03-29T17:14:02.211Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":17.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":497179,"topic_slug":"ctre-swerve-drive-library-pose-estimation-not-accounting-for-limelight-measurements","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54372,"username":"krylez","name":"Riley Brewer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/krylez/{size}/176730_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74677,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/ctre-swerve-drive-library-pose-estimation-not-accounting-for-limelight-measurements/497179/6","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3572659,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-30T00:49:41.955Z","cooked":"
krylez:

What’s the reason for the change

The new C++ implementation is compiled for both FRC and non-FRC, so FPGA time is not always available. Other features like hoot replay or simulation also don’t really want FPGA time. Device signal measurements also aren’t timestamped using FPGA time, they use the CAN frame time base (which is what our pose estimator uses now).

krylez:

do you think there’s a way to help future folks out?

ZWORX52:

if it’s possible to include these two overrides in the Phoenix X-generated project

This is already done, the current version of the generator includes the override. However, the override wasn’t added until about 3 weeks after kickoff, so projects generated before then need to manually add it.
